SILVER LINING
Fighting gamely from whistle to whistle, the Hopkins football
team found it impossible to stop the smashing line plunges and offtackle plays of the powerful Cornell eleven last Saturday. Despite
the seemingly overwhelming score, however, there were several
bright spots in the game. Newspaper men, accustomed to seeing
the "Big Red team" pile up the score on visiting elevens, were
unanimous in their praise of the spirit and gameness of the light
Baltimoreans. That Hopkins was battling every inch is illustrated
by the fact that the third quarter of Saturday's game was the first
period in which the Ithacans have not crossed the goal line of an
opponent during the present season. Cornell undoubtedly possesses
an eleven which ranks among the best three in the country and
the final result of the game is not disappointing to the Hopkins
coaches.
And, despite the gloomy predictions of local newspaper scribes,
Cornell did not succeed in crippling the entire Hopkins squad. On
the contrary, no one is suffering from more than the usual bruises
which are always prevalent after a hard-fought battle. Perhaps the
defeat by the Ithacans will prove a blessing in disguise. It undoubtedly establistied an "esprit de corps" which has been more or
less lacking during the present season. And it gave the backs excellent defensive practice which they have .not had since the Princeton
game.
Coach Van Orman is not at all pessimistic over the outcome of
last Saturday's game. It is true that he is not saying much. We
feel, however, that this is an omen of "something brewing." There
are but ten days before the Maryland game and there is much that
can happen in this time.
Last week we said: "It can be done." We repeat it!

"As I look back on my college days," said the
old grad, "it strikes me there were more men playing blind man's buff than all other games combined.
I understand this is still the case.
"Get me straight. It was no child's play. What
we were groping around for was pretty serious
business—nothing less than a career.
"Too many men are in the dark as to what they
will do after graduation. Either they neglect to
specialize in anything, or hastily select a major which
they afterwards regret.
"I know I would be considerably ahead in
business if back at college I had sat down for a few
hours'earnest thought to find out just what work I
liked best—and then gone in for it heart and soul.
"Pick the thing that appeals to you, and don't
let them tell you that particular line is overcrowded.
Talk this over with graduates you know. Talk it
over with your professors. Talk it over with the
industrial representatives next Spring. Most of all,
talk it over with yourself.
"The main thing is to get on the right track and
to keep going. There's no fun in being 'It' in the
game oflife, with every change in fate ready to push
you offan uncertain course."

Fighting gamely from whistle to whistle, the Hopkins football
team found it impossible to stop the smashing line plunges and offtackle plays of the powerful Cornell eleven last Saturday. Despite
the seemingly overwhelming score, however, there were several
bright spots in the game. Newspaper men, accustomed to seeing
the "Big Red team" pile up the score on visiting elevens, were
unanimous in their praise of the spirit and gameness of the light
Baltimoreans. That Hopkins was battling every inch is illustrated
by the fact that the third quarter of Saturday's game was the first
period in which the Ithacans have not crossed the goal line of an
opponent during the present season. Cornell undoubtedly possesses
an eleven which ranks among the best three in the country and
the final result of the game is not disappointing to the Hopkins
coaches.
And, despite the gloomy predictions of local newspaper scribes,
Cornell did not succeed in crippling the entire Hopkins squad. On
the contrary, no one is suffering from more than the usual bruises
which are always prevalent after a hard-fought battle. Perhaps the
defeat by the Ithacans will prove a blessing in disguise. It undoubtedly establistied an "esprit de corps" which has been more or
less lacking during the present season. And it gave the backs excellent defensive practice which they have .not had since the Princeton
game.
Coach Van Orman is not at all pessimistic over the outcome of
last Saturday's game. It is true that he is not saying much. We
feel, however, that this is an omen of "something brewing." There
are but ten days before the Maryland game and there is much that
can happen in this time.
Last week we said: "It can be done." We repeat it!

"As I look back on my college days," said the
old grad, "it strikes me there were more men playing blind man's buff than all other games combined.
I understand this is still the case.
"Get me straight. It was no child's play. What
we were groping around for was pretty serious
business—nothing less than a career.
"Too many men are in the dark as to what they
will do after graduation. Either they neglect to
specialize in anything, or hastily select a major which
they afterwards regret.
"I know I would be considerably ahead in
business if back at college I had sat down for a few
hours'earnest thought to find out just what work I
liked best—and then gone in for it heart and soul.
"Pick the thing that appeals to you, and don't
let them tell you that particular line is overcrowded.
Talk this over with graduates you know. Talk it
over with your professors. Talk it over with the
industrial representatives next Spring. Most of all,
talk it over with yourself.
"The main thing is to get on the right track and
to keep going. There's no fun in being 'It' in the
game oflife, with every change in fate ready to push
you offan uncertain course."
